section.title: Talking about the future
section.sectiontitle: We can use the Present Continuous, going to or will to talk about future plans.
section.text1a: I'm going to do lots and lots of shopping.
section.text2a: We're spending a month in London.
section.sectiontitle2: Use going to to talk about intentions or plans for the future. Intentions are things that you have already decided to do.
section.text3a: I am going to take a holiday in March.
section.text4a: Sue isn't going to buy that car.

section.title: Talking about the future
section.sectiontitle:
Use the Present Continuous to talk about fixed arrangements for the future. Arrangements usually involve another person (e.g. meet Paul for dinner,
go to the dentist).
section.text1: I called Michael this morning to arrange a meeting.
section.text1a: I am meeting Michael at two o'clock.
section.text2: We have already booked our tickets.
section.text2a: We aren't going to Rome, we're going to Turin.
section.sectiontitle2: In many cases you can use either going to or the Present Continuous.
section.text3a: I am playing rugby this weekend.
section.text4a: I am going to play rugby this weekend.

section.title: Talking about the future
section.sectiontitle: Use will for unplanned decisions (made while speaking), offers or promises.
section.text2a: Will you carry this box for me?
section.sectiontitle2: For general predictions you can use will or going to.
section.text3a: I think Brazil will win the next World Cup.
section.text4a: I think Brazil are going to win the next World Cup.
